name: Hydrogen
definition: Hydrogen is a chemical element with the symbol H and atomic number 1. It is the lightest and most abundant chemical element in the universe, making up about 75% of all normal matter. Under standard conditions, hydrogen is a diatomic gas with the formula H2, colorless, odorless, non-toxic, and highly combustible. It was first recognized as a distinct element by Henry Cavendish in 1766. Hydrogen exists in stars in a plasma state, where it powers nuclear fusion, producing energy and forming helium. On Earth, it occurs in water and organic compounds. Hydrogen is used in ammonia production, refining petroleum, and as rocket fuel. It is also vital in fuel cells to generate electricity. Hydrogen isotopes, such as deuterium and tritium, have specialized scientific and industrial applications.

name: Helium
definition: Helium is a chemical element with symbol He and atomic number 2. It is a colorless, odorless, tasteless, inert noble gas. Helium is the second lightest and second most abundant element in the observable universe, formed during the Big Bang and in stellar nucleosynthesis. On Earth, helium is extracted from natural gas deposits. It has extremely low chemical reactivity and is non-toxic. Helium is used in cryogenics, including cooling superconducting magnets and MRI machines, and as an inert atmosphere in welding and electronics. It inflates balloons and airships, and its low boiling point enables its use in low-temperature research. Helium isotopes, primarily 3He and 4He, are used in nuclear research and cryogenic applications. Helium was first detected in the solar spectrum in 1868.

name: Lithium
definition: Lithium is a chemical element with symbol Li and atomic number 3. It is a soft, silvery alkali metal and the lightest metal. Lithium is highly reactive, especially with water, and is usually stored in mineral oil. It occurs naturally in minerals such as spodumene and in brine deposits. Lithium is widely used in rechargeable batteries for electronics, electric vehicles, and aerospace applications. It also finds use in ceramics, glass, and pharmaceuticals as a mood stabilizer. Lithium has three naturally occurring isotopes: 6Li, 7Li, and traces of 8Li. Discovered in 1817 by Johan August Arfvedson, it is also used in nuclear fusion and heat-resistant alloys. Lithium is essential for modern energy storage and technology.

name: Beryllium
definition: Beryllium is a chemical element with symbol Be and atomic number 4. It is a rare, hard, gray metal that is lightweight and strong. Beryllium is toxic and exposure to its dust can cause chronic beryllium disease. It was discovered by Louis Nicolas Vauquelin in 1798. Beryllium has a high melting point and is resistant to corrosion. It is used in aerospace materials, nuclear reactors, X-ray windows, and precision instruments. Beryllium forms compounds such as beryllium oxide and beryllium chloride. Its alloys are essential in high-speed aircraft, missiles, and electronics. Beryllium is non-magnetic and used in specialized engineering applications. It occurs naturally in minerals like beryl and bertrandite.

name: Boron
definition: Boron is a chemical element with symbol B and atomic number 5. It is a brittle, black-brown metalloid with semiconductor properties. Boron occurs naturally in compounds such as borax and borates. It was discovered in 1808 by Humphry Davy, Joseph-Louis Gay-Lussac, and Louis-Jacques Thénard. Boron compounds are widely used in glass, ceramics, detergents, and fertilizers. Boron is essential for plant growth and used in chemical research. Its unique bonding allows formation of boranes and borides. Boron is also used in high-strength materials, pyrotechnics, and semiconductors. Boron isotopes 10B and 11B are employed in neutron capture therapy. Boron is non-toxic in small amounts and vital in industrial and scientific applications.

name: Carbon
definition: Carbon is a chemical element with symbol C and atomic number 6. It is essential for life and the basis of organic chemistry. Carbon exists in several allotropes, including graphite, diamond, graphene, and fullerenes. It occurs naturally in fossil fuels, carbonates, and organic compounds. Carbon has isotopes 12C, 13C, and 14C, the last used in radiocarbon dating. Carbon is industrially important for steelmaking, fuels, plastics, and lubricants. Antoine Lavoisier recognized it as an element in the 18th century. Carbon compounds are critical in energy transfer in biological systems. Carbon fibers are used in aerospace, sporting goods, and high-strength composites. Carbon dioxide is vital for photosynthesis and climate regulation.

name: Nitrogen
definition: Nitrogen is a chemical element with symbol N and atomic number 7. It is a colorless, odorless diatomic gas making up 78% of Earth's atmosphere. Nitrogen is essential for life as it forms amino acids, proteins, and nucleic acids. Nitrogen compounds such as ammonia and nitrates are vital for fertilizers and explosives. Discovered in 1772 by Daniel Rutherford, nitrogen has isotopes 14N and 15N. Industrially, it is used in chemical synthesis, inert atmospheres, and food packaging. Liquid nitrogen is used in cryogenics and preservation. Nitrogen gas is non-toxic and inert under normal conditions. Nitrogen fixation in nature converts atmospheric N2 to biologically usable forms. Nitrogen is critical for agriculture, industry, and biological systems.

name: Oxygen
definition: Oxygen is a chemical element with symbol O and atomic number 8. It is a colorless, odorless gas essential for respiration and combustion. Oxygen makes up 21% of Earth's atmosphere and is found in water, minerals, and organic compounds. It has stable isotopes 16O, 17O, and 18O. Oxygen was discovered in the 1770s by Carl Wilhelm Scheele and Joseph Priestley. Industrially, oxygen is used in steelmaking, welding, chemical synthesis, and medical applications. Ozone, an allotrope, protects life from UV radiation. Liquid oxygen serves as a rocket propellant. Oxygen is critical for cellular respiration and energy production. Oxygen forms compounds with nearly all elements, including oxides and acids.

name: Fluorine
definition: Fluorine is a chemical element with symbol F and atomic number 9. It is a pale yellow, highly reactive gas and the most electronegative element. Fluorine reacts with nearly all elements, forming compounds including hydrogen fluoride. Henri Moissan discovered it in 1886. Fluorine is used in toothpaste, Teflon, uranium enrichment, and pharmaceuticals. Its only stable isotope is 19F. Fluorine gas is toxic and corrosive. Fluorides are essential for dental health in small amounts. Fluorine is gaseous at room temperature. Its high reactivity makes it valuable in chemical synthesis and industrial processes.

name: Neon
definition: Neon is a chemical element with symbol Ne and atomic number 10. It is a colorless, odorless, inert noble gas present in small amounts in Earth's atmosphere. Discovered by William Ramsay and Morris Travers in 1898, neon glows reddish-orange when electrically excited. Neon has stable isotopes 20Ne, 21Ne, and 22Ne. It is non-toxic, chemically inert, and used in neon signs, high-voltage indicators, vacuum tubes, and cryogenics. Its low chemical reactivity allows long-term stability in industrial applications. Neon is commercially obtained from liquefied air. Neon is used in lighting, signage, and scientific research. It has no significant biological role.

name: Sodium
definition: Sodium is a chemical element with symbol Na and atomic number 11. It is a soft, highly reactive metal that oxidizes rapidly in air and reacts vigorously with water. Sodium occurs naturally in minerals and seawater. Discovered by Humphry Davy in 1807, it is essential for life, especially in nerve function and fluid balance. Sodium compounds include table salt (NaCl), sodium hydroxide, and sodium carbonate. Industrially, sodium is used in chemical synthesis, streetlights, and soap production. Metallic sodium is used in organic synthesis and as a reducing agent. Sodium isotopes include 23Na, the only stable one. Sodium is crucial in metallurgy and chemical industries. Sodium vapor lamps produce bright yellow light.

name: Magnesium
definition: Magnesium is a chemical element with symbol Mg and atomic number 12. It is a light, silvery metal that is relatively abundant in Earth's crust. Magnesium is essential for living organisms, particularly in chlorophyll and enzyme functions. Discovered by Sir Humphry Davy in 1808, magnesium is used in alloys, fireworks, and medicine. Magnesium burns with a bright white flame, making it useful in flares and pyrotechnics. Its isotopes include 24Mg, 25Mg, and 26Mg. Magnesium compounds, such as magnesium oxide and hydroxide, have applications in refractories and antacids. Magnesium metal is used in aerospace and automotive components. It is lightweight, strong, and corrosion-resistant. Magnesium plays a role in energy production in biological systems.

name: Aluminium
definition: Aluminium is a chemical element with symbol Al and atomic number 13. It is a lightweight, silvery metal with high corrosion resistance. Aluminium was first isolated by Hans Christian Ørsted in 1825. It is widely used in packaging, construction, aerospace, and transportation. Aluminium is highly reactive, forming a protective oxide layer. Its compounds include alumina and aluminates used in ceramics, glass, and water purification. Aluminium alloys enhance strength in engineering applications. Aluminium is the most abundant metal in Earth's crust. It is non-toxic and essential in small amounts for biological systems. Aluminium is recyclable and energy-efficient in industrial use.

name: Silicon
definition: Silicon is a chemical element with symbol Si and atomic number 14. It is a metalloid with semiconductor properties and is the second most abundant element in Earth's crust. Silicon occurs in sand, quartz, and silicate minerals. Discovered by Jöns Jacob Berzelius in 1824, it is widely used in electronics, solar cells, and glass production. Silicon forms compounds such as silicones, used in lubricants, sealants, and medical implants. Its isotopes include 28Si, 29Si, and 30Si. Silicon is critical in microelectronics, computer chips, and fiber optics. Silicon is non-toxic and biologically significant in small amounts. Silicon alloys enhance strength and heat resistance. It is essential in construction, technology, and chemical industries.

name: Phosphorus
definition: Phosphorus is a chemical element with symbol P and atomic number 15. It is a reactive, multivalent nonmetal found in several allotropic forms, including white, red, and black phosphorus. Discovered by Hennig Brand in 1669, phosphorus is essential for life, forming DNA, RNA, and ATP. Phosphorus compounds are used in fertilizers, detergents, and matches. White phosphorus is toxic and pyrophoric, whereas red and black phosphorus are more stable. Phosphorus isotopes include 31P, which is stable. It is used in chemical synthesis, agriculture, and electronics. Phosphorus cycles through the environment in the phosphorus cycle. Phosphorus is critical for energy transfer in biological systems and industrial applications. Phosphorus compounds are important in flame retardants.

name: Sulfur
definition: Sulfur is a chemical element with symbol S and atomic number 16. It is a yellow, brittle nonmetal occurring in elemental form and as sulfide and sulfate minerals. Sulfur was known since ancient times and isolated by Antoine Lavoisier. Sulfur is essential in amino acids, vitamins, and industrial chemicals. Sulfur compounds are used in sulfuric acid production, fertilizers, gunpowder, and pharmaceuticals. Sulfur has four stable isotopes: 32S, 33S, 34S, and 36S. Sulfur is used in vulcanization of rubber, fungicides, and batteries. It has a low melting point and exists in various allotropes. Sulfur is abundant in nature, particularly around volcanic areas. Sulfur is important in agriculture, industry, and biological processes.

name: Chlorine
definition: Chlorine is a chemical element with symbol Cl and atomic number 17. It is a greenish-yellow gas at room temperature with strong oxidizing properties. Chlorine was discovered by Carl Wilhelm Scheele in 1774. It is highly reactive and forms salts, such as sodium chloride, essential for life. Chlorine is used in disinfectants, PVC production, and water treatment. Chlorine isotopes include 35Cl and 37Cl. Chlorine is toxic and corrosive, requiring careful handling. It is used in chemical synthesis, bleaching, and pharmaceuticals. Chlorine gas played a role historically in warfare. It reacts with metals and nonmetals to form chlorides. Chlorine is crucial in industry and public health applications.

name: Argon
definition: Argon is a chemical element with symbol Ar and atomic number 18. It is a colorless, odorless, inert noble gas that constitutes about 0.93% of Earth's atmosphere. Discovered by Lord Rayleigh and William Ramsay in 1894, argon is chemically non-reactive. Argon has three stable isotopes: 36Ar, 38Ar, and 40Ar. It is used in welding, lighting, and as an inert atmosphere in chemical and industrial processes. Liquid argon is used as a cryogenic refrigerant. Argon is non-toxic and chemically stable. It protects materials from oxidation and is employed in metal fabrication. Argon is also used in scientific research, gas-filled lamps, and insulation. Argon is commercially obtained from the fractional distillation of liquid air. It plays a vital role in preserving reactive elements and compounds.

name: Potassium
definition: Potassium is a chemical element with symbol K and atomic number 19. It is a soft, silvery metal that reacts vigorously with water, producing hydrogen gas and heat. Potassium occurs naturally in minerals and seawater and is essential for plant and animal life. It was first isolated by Sir Humphry Davy in 1807. Potassium compounds, such as potassium chloride and potassium nitrate, are widely used in fertilizers, explosives, and food processing. Potassium ions play a crucial role in nerve transmission, muscle contraction, and fluid balance in living organisms. Potassium is highly reactive and stored under oil to prevent oxidation. Its isotopes include 39K, 40K, and 41K, with 40K being radioactive. Industrially, potassium is used in glass production, soap, and chemical synthesis.

name: Calcium
definition: Calcium is a chemical element with symbol Ca and atomic number 20. It is a silvery-white, moderately hard metal and is the fifth most abundant element in Earth's crust. Discovered by Sir Humphry Davy in 1808, calcium plays an essential role in biology, particularly in bones, teeth, and cellular signaling. Calcium reacts with water and acids, forming hydrogen gas and calcium hydroxide. Calcium compounds include calcium carbonate, calcium oxide, and calcium sulfate, widely used in construction, cement, and fertilizers. Its isotopes include 40Ca, 42Ca, 43Ca, 44Ca, and 48Ca. Calcium ions are vital in muscle contraction, nerve transmission, and blood clotting. Calcium metal is used in metallurgy, chemical reduction, and alloy formation. Calcium is critical in industrial, chemical, and biological systems.

name: Scandium
definition: Scandium is a chemical element with symbol Sc and atomic number 21. It is a silvery-white, soft transition metal that was discovered in 1879 by Lars Fredrik Nilson. Scandium occurs naturally in rare minerals such as thortveitite and is often obtained from byproducts of uranium refining. It is used in aerospace components, high-intensity lamps, and sports equipment. Scandium alloys enhance strength, lightness, and corrosion resistance. Its stable isotope is 45Sc. Scandium is chemically similar to the rare earth elements and can form compounds with oxygen, halogens, and nitrogen. It is used in small quantities due to its rarity and cost. Scandium has no known biological role. It is primarily valued for specialized industrial and scientific applications.

name: Titanium
definition: Titanium is a chemical element with symbol Ti and atomic number 22. It is a strong, lustrous transition metal with excellent corrosion resistance and a low density. Titanium occurs naturally in minerals like ilmenite and rutile and was discovered in 1791 by William Gregor. It is used in aerospace, medical implants, sporting goods, and chemical equipment. Titanium alloys have high strength-to-weight ratios and are used in aircraft, ships, and missiles. Its isotopes include 46Ti, 47Ti, 48Ti, 49Ti, and 50Ti. Titanium forms a protective oxide layer, making it highly durable. It is non-toxic and biocompatible. Titanium is also used in pigments, sunscreens, and jewelry. Its compounds are valuable in catalysis, coatings, and electronics.

name: Vanadium
definition: Vanadium is a chemical element with symbol V and atomic number 23. It is a hard, silvery-gray transition metal discovered by Andrés Manuel del Río in 1801. Vanadium is found in minerals such as vanadinite and magnetite. It is primarily used to strengthen steel, producing high-strength alloys for tools, pipelines, and aerospace components. Vanadium compounds are catalysts in chemical processes and are used in batteries, ceramics, and pigments. Its stable isotopes include 50V and 51V. Vanadium exhibits multiple oxidation states, making it versatile in chemistry. It has no known essential biological role but is used in trace amounts in some enzymes. Vanadium is resistant to corrosion and widely applied in metallurgy and industrial chemistry.

name: Chromium
definition: Chromium is a chemical element with symbol Cr and atomic number 24. It is a lustrous, hard, and corrosion-resistant transition metal discovered in 1797 by Louis Nicolas Vauquelin. Chromium occurs naturally in chromite ores and is used extensively in stainless steel, plating, and pigments. Chromium compounds include chromates and dichromates, used in dyes, tanning, and corrosion protection. Its stable isotopes include 50Cr, 52Cr, 53Cr, and 54Cr. Chromium exhibits multiple oxidation states and forms colorful compounds. It is essential in trace amounts for biological systems, aiding glucose metabolism. Chromium metal is used in alloys, refractories, and catalysts. It is resistant to oxidation and highly durable. Chromium plays a significant role in industrial, chemical, and metallurgical applications.

name: Manganese
definition: Manganese is a chemical element with symbol Mn and atomic number 25. It is a grayish-white, hard transition metal discovered in 1774 by Johan Gottlieb Gahn. Manganese occurs naturally in minerals such as pyrolusite and rhodochrosite. It is essential for steelmaking, improving hardness, strength, and wear resistance. Manganese compounds are used in batteries, ceramics, fertilizers, and pigments. Its isotopes include 55Mn, the only stable isotope. Manganese is also a trace element important in biological systems, aiding enzyme function and metabolism. It is reactive with acids and oxidizers. Industrially, manganese is used in chemical production, alloys, and metal processing. Manganese has high melting point and durability for engineering applications.

name: Iron
definition: Iron is a chemical element with symbol Fe and atomic number 26. It is a strong, silvery-gray transition metal and one of the most abundant elements on Earth. Iron was used since ancient times and recognized as an element in the 18th century. Iron occurs naturally in ores like hematite and magnetite. It is essential in biological systems as part of hemoglobin and enzymes. Industrially, iron is used to produce steel, cast iron, and alloys for construction, machinery, and transportation. Iron has isotopes 54Fe, 56Fe, 57Fe, and 58Fe. Iron reacts with oxygen and moisture, forming rust. Its compounds are used in pigments, magnets, and catalysts. Iron is vital for industry, technology, and biology.

name: Cobalt
definition: Cobalt is a chemical element with symbol Co and atomic number 27. It is a hard, lustrous, silver-gray transition metal discovered by Georg Brandt in 1735. Cobalt occurs naturally in minerals like cobaltite and erythrite. It is used in batteries, magnets, high-strength alloys, and catalysts. Cobalt compounds, such as cobalt chloride, are used in pigments, inks, and ceramics. Its stable isotope is 59Co. Cobalt is essential in trace amounts for vitamin B12 in biological systems. It is resistant to corrosion and high temperatures. Cobalt alloys are critical in aerospace, medical implants, and industrial applications. Cobalt is also employed in rechargeable battery technologies.

name: Nickel
definition: Nickel is a chemical element with symbol Ni and atomic number 28. It is a silvery-white, hard, ductile transition metal discovered in 1751 by Axel Fredrik Cronstedt. Nickel occurs naturally in minerals such as pentlandite and laterites. It is widely used in stainless steel, alloys, coinage, and plating. Nickel compounds are employed in batteries, ceramics, and catalysts. Its stable isotopes include 58Ni, 60Ni, 61Ni, 62Ni, and 64Ni. Nickel is corrosion-resistant, magnetic, and industrially valuable. It has no essential biological role but is trace-essential for some microorganisms. Nickel is used in electroplating, chemical production, and electronics. Nickel alloys are critical in aerospace, chemical, and engineering applications.

name: Copper
definition: Copper is a chemical element with symbol Cu and atomic number 29. It is a reddish, malleable, ductile transition metal known since ancient times. Copper occurs naturally in ores such as chalcopyrite and malachite. It is widely used in electrical wiring, plumbing, roofing, and industrial machinery. Copper compounds, like copper sulfate, are used in agriculture, pigments, and antifouling coatings. Its isotopes include 63Cu and 65Cu. Copper has excellent electrical and thermal conductivity. It is an essential trace element for humans, aiding in enzymes and red blood cell formation. Copper is resistant to corrosion and forms protective patina. It is employed in electronics, renewable energy, and building materials.

name: Zinc
definition: Zinc is a chemical element with symbol Zn and atomic number 30. It is a bluish-white, moderately reactive transition metal. Zinc occurs naturally in minerals such as sphalerite and smithsonite. Discovered by Andreas Marggraf in 1746, zinc is widely used for galvanizing steel, alloy production, and batteries. Zinc compounds, such as zinc oxide and zinc sulfate, are used in rubber, cosmetics, and agriculture. Its stable isotopes include 64Zn, 66Zn, 67Zn, 68Zn, and 70Zn. Zinc is essential for biological systems, supporting enzyme function and immune response. Zinc resists corrosion and is non-toxic in moderate amounts. It is also used in die-casting, electronics, and chemical manufacturing. Zinc plays a critical role in industry and health.

name: Gallium
definition: Gallium is a chemical element with symbol Ga and atomic number 31. It is a soft, silvery post-transition metal with a low melting point. Gallium was discovered in 1875 by Paul-Émile Lecoq de Boisbaudran. It occurs in trace amounts in bauxite and zinc ores. Gallium is used in semiconductors, LEDs, solar panels, and thermometers. Its stable isotopes are 69Ga and 71Ga. Gallium is non-toxic and does not crystallize in its liquid state at room temperature. It forms alloys with many metals. Gallium compounds are used in electronics and optoelectronics. Gallium’s properties are valuable in high-tech applications and scientific research. Gallium is important in modern electronics, photonics, and materials science.

name: Germanium
definition: Germanium is a chemical element with symbol Ge and atomic number 32. It is a lustrous, gray-white metalloid with semiconductor properties. Germanium was discovered by Clemens Winkler in 1886. It occurs naturally in trace amounts in sphalerite and other minerals. Germanium is used in semiconductors, fiber optics, infrared optics, and solar cells. Its stable isotopes are 70Ge, 72Ge, 73Ge, 74Ge, and 76Ge. Germanium compounds are employed in electronics, phosphors, and polymerization catalysts. Germanium is non-toxic and biocompatible. Its unique electronic properties make it vital in microelectronics. Germanium is used in high-performance devices, optical systems, and advanced materials. Germanium is essential in high-tech engineering and research applications.

name: Arsenic
definition: Arsenic is a chemical element with symbol As and atomic number 33. It is a brittle metalloid, gray or yellow in appearance, and known for its toxicity. Arsenic occurs naturally in minerals such as arsenopyrite and realgar. It was recognized as an element by Albertus Magnus in the 13th century. Arsenic is used in semiconductors, pesticides, wood preservatives, and alloys. Its isotopes include 75As, the only stable isotope. Arsenic compounds have historical medicinal uses but are highly toxic. Arsenic forms alloys to improve hardness and corrosion resistance. It is used in electronics, research, and chemical synthesis. Arsenic requires careful handling due to its toxicity and environmental impact. It is critical in metallurgy, electronics, and chemical applications.

name: Selenium
definition: Selenium is a chemical element with symbol Se and atomic number 34. It is a nonmetal with several allotropes, including gray, red, and black forms. Selenium occurs naturally in sulfide ores and was discovered by Jöns Jacob Berzelius in 1817. It is used in electronics, glassmaking, pigments, and nutrition supplements. Selenium has isotopes including 74Se, 76Se, 77Se, 78Se, 80Se, and 82Se. Selenium is essential in small amounts for biological systems, functioning in antioxidant enzymes. It is also used in photocells, solar cells, and rectifiers. Selenium compounds have industrial and chemical applications. Selenium is non-toxic at low concentrations but can be toxic at high doses. It is valuable in modern technology, health, and industry.

name: Bromine
definition: Bromine is a chemical element with symbol Br and atomic number 35. It is a reddish-brown liquid at room temperature and the only nonmetallic element that is liquid under standard conditions. Bromine was discovered by Antoine Balard in 1826. It occurs naturally in seawater and brines. Bromine is used in flame retardants, photography chemicals, water treatment, and pharmaceuticals. Its isotopes include 79Br and 81Br. Bromine is highly reactive and toxic, requiring careful handling. Bromine forms compounds such as bromides for industrial and chemical use. Bromine’s reactivity makes it useful in organic synthesis. Bromine has applications in agriculture, medicine, and chemical industries. Bromine is valuable in fire safety and chemical production.

name: Krypton
definition: Krypton is a chemical element with symbol Kr and atomic number 36. It is a colorless, odorless noble gas found in trace amounts in Earth's atmosphere. Discovered by William Ramsay and Morris Travers in 1898, krypton is chemically inert and non-toxic. Krypton has several isotopes, including 78Kr, 80Kr, 82Kr, 83Kr, 84Kr, and 86Kr. Krypton is used in lighting, such as fluorescent lamps, high-performance bulbs, and photography. Its compounds are rare but include krypton difluoride. Krypton is employed in scientific research, lasers, and gas mixtures. It is stable and has no biological role. Krypton’s chemical inertness allows long-term storage in industrial applications. Krypton is extracted commercially from liquefied air. Krypton is essential in lighting, lasers, and research technology.

name: Rubidium
definition: Rubidium is a chemical element with symbol Rb and atomic number 37. It is a soft, silvery-white alkali metal discovered by Robert Bunsen and Gustav Kirchhoff in 1861. Rubidium occurs naturally in minerals like lepidolite and pollucite. It reacts violently with water and is highly reactive with air. Rubidium isotopes include 85Rb and 87Rb, the latter being radioactive. It is used in research, atomic clocks, and photoelectric cells. Rubidium compounds find applications in specialty glasses and chemical reagents. It has no known essential biological role but is sometimes used in medical imaging. Rubidium is valuable in high-precision scientific experiments and advanced electronics.

name: Strontium
definition: Strontium is a chemical element with symbol Sr and atomic number 38. It is a soft, silvery metal discovered by Adair Crawford in 1790. Strontium occurs in minerals such as celestine and strontianite. It reacts with water, producing hydrogen gas. Strontium isotopes include 84Sr, 86Sr, 87Sr, and 88Sr. It is used in fireworks for red color, in magnets, ferrite materials, and ceramics. Strontium compounds are employed in ferrite magnets, glass, and electronics. Strontium has some biological trace functions but is not essential. It is used in radiation therapy and research applications. Strontium is moderately reactive and stored carefully to prevent oxidation.

name: Yttrium
definition: Yttrium is a chemical element with symbol Y and atomic number 39. It is a silvery, ductile transition metal discovered by Johan Gadolin in 1794. Yttrium occurs naturally in rare-earth minerals such as xenotime and monazite. It has isotopes including 89Y. Yttrium is used in LEDs, superconductors, phosphors, and ceramics. Its compounds are important in materials science and electronics. Yttrium is stable in air due to an oxide layer and does not have a biological role. It is used in solid-state devices and microwave filters. Yttrium alloys enhance strength and corrosion resistance. Its unique properties make it valuable in modern technology and high-performance materials.

name: Zirconium
definition: Zirconium is a chemical element with symbol Zr and atomic number 40. It is a lustrous, gray transition metal discovered by Martin Heinrich Klaproth in 1789. Zirconium occurs in minerals such as zircon and baddeleyite. It is resistant to corrosion and used in nuclear reactors, ceramics, and alloys. Zirconium isotopes include 90Zr, 91Zr, 92Zr, 94Zr, and 96Zr. Zirconium compounds are applied in refractory materials, chemical equipment, and dental ceramics. It is non-toxic and stable in air. Zirconium alloys improve strength and heat resistance. It is used in specialized industrial, chemical, and scientific applications. Zirconium is critical for high-performance engineering and research.

name: Niobium
definition: Niobium is a chemical element with symbol Nb and atomic number 41. It is a soft, gray transition metal discovered by Charles Hatchett in 1801. Niobium occurs naturally in minerals such as columbite and pyrochlore. Its isotopes include 93Nb, the only stable isotope. Niobium is used in superconducting materials, steel alloys, and jet engines. Niobium compounds are employed in electronics, catalysts, and jewelry. Niobium resists corrosion and high temperatures. It has no known biological role. Niobium alloys enhance strength, ductility, and heat resistance. It is valuable in aerospace, chemical, and scientific applications.

name: Molybdenum
definition: Molybdenum is a chemical element with symbol Mo and atomic number 42. It is a silvery transition metal discovered by Carl Wilhelm Scheele in 1778. Molybdenum occurs in minerals such as molybdenite. Its isotopes include 92Mo, 94Mo, 95Mo, 96Mo, 97Mo, 98Mo, and 100Mo. Molybdenum is used in steel alloys, electronics, and lubricants. Its compounds act as catalysts in chemical reactions. Molybdenum is essential in trace amounts for enzymes in living organisms. It has a high melting point and is corrosion-resistant. Molybdenum is employed in aerospace, energy, and industrial applications. It is a versatile industrial and scientific metal.

name: Technetium
definition: Technetium is a chemical element with symbol Tc and atomic number 43. It is a radioactive, silvery-gray metal discovered by Carlo Perrier and Emilio Segrè in 1937. Technetium occurs naturally in trace amounts but is mostly produced synthetically. Its isotopes include 98Tc and 99Tc. Technetium is used in medical imaging, research, and radiopharmaceuticals. It forms compounds such as technetium oxides and halides. Technetium has no biological role due to its radioactivity. It is moderately corrosion-resistant and chemically reactive. Technetium is valuable in nuclear medicine and scientific research. It is primarily used in diagnostic and experimental applications.

name: Ruthenium
definition: Ruthenium is a chemical element with symbol Ru and atomic number 44. It is a hard, silvery transition metal discovered by Karl Ernst Claus in 1844. Ruthenium occurs in ores such as pentlandite and pyroxene. Its isotopes include 96Ru, 98Ru, 99Ru, 100Ru, 101Ru, 102Ru, and 104Ru. Ruthenium is used in electronics, catalysts, and alloys. Its compounds are applied in chemical synthesis, electrical contacts, and plating. Ruthenium is resistant to corrosion and oxidation. It has no biological role. Ruthenium improves hardness and durability in alloys. It is valuable in industrial, chemical, and electronic applications.

name: Rhodium
definition: Rhodium is a chemical element with symbol Rh and atomic number 45. It is a rare, silvery-white transition metal discovered by William Hyde Wollaston in 1803. Rhodium occurs in platinum ores. Its stable isotope is 103Rh. Rhodium is used in catalytic converters, jewelry, and plating. Rhodium compounds are applied in chemical reactions and reflective coatings. It is corrosion-resistant, chemically inert, and highly durable. Rhodium has no biological role. It improves alloy hardness and heat resistance. Rhodium is valuable in automotive, industrial, and jewelry applications.

name: Palladium
definition: Palladium is a chemical element with symbol Pd and atomic number 46. It is a lustrous, silvery-white transition metal discovered by William Hyde Wollaston in 1803. Palladium occurs in nickel and platinum ores. Its stable isotope is 106Pd, among others. Palladium is used in catalytic converters, electronics, and jewelry. Palladium compounds act as catalysts in chemical reactions and hydrogen storage. It is corrosion-resistant and stable under normal conditions. Palladium has no known biological role. Palladium alloys improve strength and durability. It is important in automotive, industrial, and chemical industries.

name: Silver
definition: Silver is a chemical element with symbol Ag and atomic number 47. It is a lustrous, white transition metal known since ancient times. Silver occurs naturally in ores like argentite. Its isotopes include 107Ag and 109Ag. Silver is used in jewelry, coins, electronics, and photography. Silver compounds are applied in catalysis, medicine, and antibacterial materials. Silver has excellent electrical and thermal conductivity. It is non-toxic in moderate amounts and has trace biological importance. Silver alloys enhance strength and corrosion resistance. Silver is valuable in industrial, decorative, and electronic applications.

name: Cadmium
definition: Cadmium is a chemical element with symbol Cd and atomic number 48. It is a soft, bluish-white transition metal discovered by Friedrich Stromeyer in 1817. Cadmium occurs in zinc ores and is obtained as a byproduct of zinc refining. Its isotopes include 106Cd, 108Cd, 110Cd, 111Cd, 112Cd, 113Cd, 114Cd, and 116Cd. Cadmium is used in batteries, pigments, coatings, and alloys. Cadmium compounds are toxic and require careful handling. It has no essential biological role. Cadmium is corrosion-resistant and has a low melting point. It is applied in electroplating, photovoltaic cells, and industrial processes. Cadmium is valuable in specialized industrial and chemical applications.

name: Indium
definition: Indium is a chemical element with symbol In and atomic number 49. It is a soft, silvery post-transition metal discovered by Ferdinand Reich and Hieronymous Theodor Richter in 1863. Indium occurs in zinc ores and as a byproduct of zinc refining. Its isotopes include 113In and 115In. Indium is used in semiconductors, LCDs, solders, and coatings. Indium compounds are applied in electronics, photovoltaics, and research. It has no biological role. Indium is soft, malleable, and has a low melting point. It is valuable in electronics, advanced materials, and high-tech applications. Indium enhances properties of alloys and coatings.

name: Tin
definition: Tin is a chemical element with symbol Sn and atomic number 50. It is a silvery, malleable post-transition metal known since ancient times. Tin occurs naturally in cassiterite and other ores. Its isotopes include 112Sn, 114Sn, 115Sn, 116Sn, 117Sn, 118Sn, 119Sn, 120Sn, 122Sn, and 124Sn. Tin is used in coatings, alloys, solders, and chemical applications. Tin compounds are employed in plastics, glass, and stabilizers. Tin is non-toxic in metallic form. Tin has low melting point and corrosion resistance. Tin alloys enhance strength, durability, and malleability. Tin is important in industry, construction, and electronics.

name: Antimony
definition: Antimony is a chemical element with symbol Sb and atomic number 51. It is a brittle metalloid with a silvery appearance, known since ancient times. Antimony occurs in stibnite ores. Its isotopes include 121Sb and 123Sb. Antimony is used in flame retardants, alloys, electronics, and semiconductors. Antimony compounds are applied in paints, ceramics, and chemicals. It has no essential biological role. Antimony is corrosion-resistant and chemically stable. Antimony enhances alloy hardness and durability. Antimony is valuable in industrial, chemical, and technological applications.

name: Tellurium
definition: Tellurium is a chemical element with symbol Te and atomic number 52. It is a brittle metalloid with silvery-white appearance. Tellurium occurs in minerals like tellurite and calaverite. Its isotopes include 120Te, 122Te, 123Te, 124Te, 125Te, 126Te, 128Te, and 130Te. Tellurium is used in alloys, semiconductors, and solar panels. Tellurium compounds are applied in electronics, thermoelectric devices, and chemical production. It has no essential biological role. Tellurium is chemically reactive and moderately toxic. Tellurium enhances conductivity, corrosion resistance, and thermal properties in materials. Tellurium is valuable in advanced technology, energy, and industrial applications.

name: Iodine
definition: Iodine is a chemical element with symbol I and atomic number 53. It is a purple-black solid that sublimates easily, discovered in 1811 by Bernard Courtois. Iodine occurs naturally in seawater and certain minerals. Its isotopes include 127I. Iodine is essential for thyroid hormone production and is used as a disinfectant. Iodine compounds are applied in medicine, nutrition, and chemical synthesis. It is moderately reactive and toxic in large amounts. Iodine is used in photography, pharmaceuticals, and research. Iodine enhances human health, industrial processes, and chemical applications. It is valuable in medicine, science, and technology.

name: Xenon
definition: Xenon is a chemical element with symbol Xe and atomic number 54. It is a colorless, odorless noble gas discovered by William Ramsay and Morris Travers in 1898. Xenon occurs in trace amounts in Earth's atmosphere. Its isotopes include 124Xe, 126Xe, 128Xe, 129Xe, 130Xe, 131Xe, 132Xe, 134Xe, and 136Xe. Xenon is used in lighting, anesthesia, ion propulsion, and research. Its compounds, though rare, include xenon fluorides. Xenon is chemically inert and non-toxic. Xenon is used in high-intensity lamps, lasers, and medical imaging. Xenon has no biological role. Xenon is important in scientific, medical, and industrial applications.

name: Cesium
definition: Cesium is a chemical element with symbol Cs and atomic number 55. It is a soft, golden alkali metal discovered by Robert Bunsen and Gustav Kirchhoff in 1860. Cesium occurs in minerals like pollucite. It is highly reactive and reacts explosively with water. Its isotopes include 133Cs, the most stable, and radioactive isotopes like 137Cs. Cesium is used in atomic clocks, photoelectric cells, and research. Cesium compounds are applied in drilling fluids, vacuum tubes, and specialty glasses. It has no known biological role. Cesium is valuable in scientific precision instruments and high-tech applications. Cesium must be handled carefully due to its extreme reactivity.

name: Barium
definition: Barium is a chemical element with symbol Ba and atomic number 56. It is a soft, silvery alkaline earth metal discovered by Sir Humphry Davy in 1808. Barium occurs in minerals such as barite and witherite. Its isotopes include 130Ba and 138Ba. Barium is used in fireworks, drilling fluids, and medical imaging. Barium compounds like barium sulfate are used in radiology as contrast agents. Barium reacts with air and water, so it is stored under oil. It has no biological role but is toxic in soluble forms. Barium enhances industrial and scientific applications. It is employed in ceramics, electronics, and specialized materials.

name: Lanthanum
definition: Lanthanum is a chemical element with symbol La and atomic number 57. It is a soft, silvery rare-earth metal discovered by Carl Gustaf Mosander in 1839. Lanthanum occurs in minerals such as monazite and bastnäsite. Its isotopes include 138La, 139La. Lanthanum is used in catalysts, camera lenses, and battery electrodes. Lanthanum compounds are applied in optics, glass additives, and hydrogen storage. It has no essential biological role. Lanthanum is moderately reactive and resistant to corrosion. It is valuable in electronics, optics, and high-tech materials. Lanthanum enhances the performance of alloys and specialized equipment.

name: Cerium
definition: Cerium is a chemical element with symbol Ce and atomic number 58. It is a soft, silvery rare-earth metal discovered by Wilhelm Hisinger and Jöns Jacob Berzelius in 1803. Cerium occurs in minerals such as monazite and bastnäsite. Its isotopes include 140Ce and 142Ce. Cerium is used in catalysts, glass polishing, and alloy production. Cerium compounds are employed in automotive catalytic converters and phosphors. Cerium has no known biological role. It is chemically reactive but stable in air due to oxide formation. Cerium enhances industrial processes and materials. It is important in scientific research and technology applications.

name: Praseodymium
definition: Praseodymium is a chemical element with symbol Pr and atomic number 59. It is a soft, silvery rare-earth metal discovered by Carl Auer von Welsbach in 1885. Praseodymium occurs in minerals like monazite and bastnäsite. Its isotopes include 141Pr. It is used in magnets, ceramics, and aircraft engines. Praseodymium compounds are applied in glass coloring, electrodes, and alloys. It has no biological role. It is moderately reactive, forming a protective oxide layer. Praseodymium enhances material strength and electronic performance. It is valuable in high-tech, aerospace, and scientific applications.

name: Neodymium
definition: Neodymium is a chemical element with symbol Nd and atomic number 60. It is a silvery rare-earth metal discovered by Carl Auer von Welsbach in 1885. Neodymium occurs in minerals such as monazite and bastnäsite. Its isotopes include 142Nd and 144Nd. Neodymium is used in powerful magnets, lasers, and electronics. Neodymium compounds are employed in glass coloring, ceramics, and optical devices. It has no biological role. Neodymium is reactive but forms a stable oxide layer. It enhances magnet strength and material performance. Neodymium is crucial for modern technology and scientific instruments.

name: Promethium
definition: Promethium is a chemical element with symbol Pm and atomic number 61. It is a radioactive rare-earth metal discovered by Jacob A. Marinsky, Lawrence E. Glendenin, and Charles D. Coryell in 1945. Promethium does not occur naturally in significant amounts and is produced synthetically. Its isotopes include 145Pm and 147Pm. Promethium is used in luminous paint, nuclear batteries, and research. Its compounds are radioactive and handled with care. Promethium has no biological role. It is chemically reactive and unstable. Promethium is valuable in scientific research, energy, and specialized applications. It is stored under inert conditions to prevent oxidation.

name: Samarium
definition: Samarium is a chemical element with symbol Sm and atomic number 62. It is a silvery rare-earth metal discovered by Paul Émile Lecoq de Boisbaudran in 1879. Samarium occurs in minerals such as monazite and bastnäsite. Its isotopes include 144Sm, 147Sm, and 152Sm. Samarium is used in magnets, nuclear reactors, and lasers. Samarium compounds are applied in electronics, catalysts, and specialized ceramics. It has no biological role. Samarium is moderately reactive and corrosion-resistant. It enhances magnetic and material properties. Samarium is important in high-tech, scientific, and industrial applications.

name: Europium
definition: Europium is a chemical element with symbol Eu and atomic number 63. It is a silvery rare-earth metal discovered by Eugène-Anatole Demarçay in 1896. Europium occurs in minerals such as monazite and bastnäsite. Its isotopes include 151Eu and 153Eu. Europium is used in phosphors, TV screens, and lasers. Europium compounds are applied in lighting, electronics, and nuclear control rods. It has no biological role. Europium is reactive but forms a protective oxide layer. Europium enhances luminescence and electronic performance. It is valuable in display technology, lighting, and scientific applications.

name: Gadolinium
definition: Gadolinium is a chemical element with symbol Gd and atomic number 64. It is a silvery rare-earth metal discovered by Jean Charles Galissard de Marignac in 1880. Gadolinium occurs in minerals such as monazite and xenotime. Its isotopes include 157Gd and 158Gd. Gadolinium is used in MRI contrast agents, magnets, and nuclear reactors. Gadolinium compounds are applied in electronics, phosphors, and catalysts. It has no biological role but is moderately toxic in large amounts. It is reactive but stable in air. Gadolinium enhances magnetic, electronic, and industrial applications. It is valuable in medical, scientific, and technological fields.

name: Terbium
definition: Terbium is a chemical element with symbol Tb and atomic number 65. It is a silvery rare-earth metal discovered by Carl Gustaf Mosander in 1843. Terbium occurs in minerals such as cerite and gadolinite. Its isotopes include 159Tb. Terbium is used in phosphors, magnets, and electronics. Terbium compounds are applied in solid-state devices, lighting, and research. It has no biological role. Terbium is moderately reactive and stable in air. Terbium enhances luminescence, magnetism, and material properties. It is valuable in modern technology, scientific research, and electronics.

name: Dysprosium
definition: Dysprosium is a chemical element with symbol Dy and atomic number 66. It is a silvery rare-earth metal discovered by Paul Émile Lecoq de Boisbaudran in 1886. Dysprosium occurs in minerals such as xenotime and monazite. Its isotopes include 161Dy, 162Dy, and 163Dy. Dysprosium is used in magnets, lasers, and nuclear reactors. Dysprosium compounds are applied in lighting, electronics, and research. It has no biological role. Dysprosium is chemically reactive and forms a protective oxide layer. Dysprosium enhances magnetic and material properties. It is important in high-tech, industrial, and scientific applications.

name: Holmium
definition: Holmium is a chemical element with symbol Ho and atomic number 67. It is a silvery rare-earth metal discovered by Marc Delafontaine and Jacques-Louis Soret in 1878. Holmium occurs in minerals like monazite and gadolinite. Its isotopes include 165Ho. Holmium is used in magnets, lasers, and nuclear research. Holmium compounds are applied in specialized materials, glass coloring, and electrodes. It has no biological role. Holmium is reactive and forms a protective oxide layer. Holmium enhances magnetic, optical, and material properties. It is valuable in scientific, industrial, and technological applications.

name: Erbium
definition: Erbium is a chemical element with symbol Er and atomic number 68. It is a silvery rare-earth metal discovered by Carl Gustaf Mosander in 1843. Erbium occurs in minerals like monazite and xenotime. Its isotopes include 166Er, 167Er, and 168Er. Erbium is used in fiber optics, lasers, and nuclear technology. Erbium compounds are applied in ceramics, glass coloring, and optical devices. It has no biological role. Erbium is moderately reactive and stable in air. Erbium enhances optical, electronic, and magnetic applications. It is valuable in telecommunications, scientific research, and materials technology.

name: Thulium
definition: Thulium is a chemical element with symbol Tm and atomic number 69. It is a silvery rare-earth metal discovered by Per Teodor Cleve in 1879. Thulium occurs in minerals such as monazite and gadolinite. Its isotopes include 169Tm. Thulium is used in lasers, X-ray machines, and research. Thulium compounds are applied in solid-state devices and specialized instruments. It has no biological role. Thulium is moderately reactive and forms a protective oxide layer. Thulium enhances optical and electronic properties. It is valuable in scientific, medical, and high-tech applications.

name: Ytterbium
definition: Ytterbium is a chemical element with symbol Yb and atomic number 70. It is a soft, silvery rare-earth metal discovered by Jean Charles Galissard de Marignac in 1878. Ytterbium occurs in minerals such as monazite and xenotime. Its isotopes include 174Yb. Ytterbium is used in lasers, atomic clocks, and research. Ytterbium compounds are applied in electronics, chemical reactions, and metallurgy. It has no biological role. Ytterbium is moderately reactive and stable in air. Ytterbium enhances precision instruments and electronic applications. It is valuable in scientific, industrial, and technological research.

name: Lutetium
definition: Lutetium is a chemical element with symbol Lu and atomic number 71. It is a silvery rare-earth metal discovered by Georges Urbain in 1907. Lutetium occurs in minerals like monazite and xenotime. Its isotopes include 175Lu and 176Lu. Lutetium is used in PET scan detectors, catalysts, and research. Lutetium compounds are applied in specialized ceramics and electronics. It has no biological role. Lutetium is chemically stable and moderately reactive. Lutetium enhances material properties and industrial applications. It is valuable in scientific, medical, and high-tech fields.

name: Hafnium
definition: Hafnium is a chemical element with symbol Hf and atomic number 72. It is a silvery transition metal discovered by Dirk Coster and George de Hevesy in 1923. Hafnium occurs in zirconium ores. Its isotopes include 176Hf. Hafnium is used in nuclear reactors, superalloys, and semiconductors. Hafnium compounds are applied in ceramics, electronics, and high-temperature materials. It has no biological role. Hafnium is corrosion-resistant and heat-tolerant. Hafnium enhances material performance in aerospace and nuclear applications. It is valuable in industrial, scientific, and technological fields.

name: Tantalum
definition: Tantalum is a chemical element with symbol Ta and atomic number 73. It is a hard, corrosion-resistant transition metal discovered by Anders Ekeberg in 1802. Tantalum occurs in minerals such as tantalite. Its isotopes include 180Ta. Tantalum is used in electronics, implants, and alloys. Tantalum compounds are applied in capacitors, surgical instruments, and chemical equipment. It has no biological role. Tantalum is resistant to corrosion and high temperatures. Tantalum enhances material durability and performance. It is valuable in industrial, medical, and technological applications.

name: Tungsten
definition: Tungsten is a chemical element with symbol W and atomic number 74. It is a dense, gray transition metal discovered by Juan José and Fausto Elhuyar in 1783. Tungsten occurs in minerals such as wolframite and scheelite. Its isotopes include 182W and 184W. Tungsten has the highest melting point of all metals and is used in filaments, cutting tools, and superalloys. Tungsten compounds are applied in electronics, catalysts, and radiation shielding. It has no biological role. Tungsten is corrosion-resistant and strong. It enhances material durability, industrial tools, and high-temperature applications. Tungsten is valuable in science, industry, and technology.

name: Rhenium
definition: Rhenium is a chemical element with symbol Re and atomic number 75. It is a silvery transition metal discovered by Walter Noddack, Ida Noddack, and Otto Berg in 1925. Rhenium occurs in trace amounts in molybdenite. Its isotopes include 185Re and 187Re. Rhenium is used in jet engines, catalysts, and thermocouples. Rhenium compounds are applied in high-temperature superalloys and chemical reactions. It has no biological role. Rhenium is dense, corrosion-resistant, and rare. It enhances industrial and aerospace performance. Rhenium is highly valuable in technology and scientific applications.

name: Osmium
definition: Osmium is a chemical element with symbol Os and atomic number 76. It is a dense, bluish-white transition metal discovered by Smithson Tennant in 1803. Osmium occurs in platinum ores and alloys. Its isotopes include 192Os. Osmium is used in alloys, fountain pen tips, and electrical contacts. Osmium compounds are applied in catalysis, chemical synthesis, and instruments. It has no biological role. Osmium is extremely dense and corrosion-resistant. It enhances material hardness and industrial tools. Osmium is valuable in high-precision and technological applications.

name: Iridium
definition: Iridium is a chemical element with symbol Ir and atomic number 77. It is a hard, dense transition metal discovered by Smithson Tennant in 1803. Iridium occurs in platinum ores. Its isotopes include 191Ir and 193Ir. Iridium is used in spark plugs, crucibles, and electrical contacts. Iridium compounds are applied in catalysis, electronics, and high-temperature equipment. It has no biological role. Iridium is extremely corrosion-resistant. It enhances durability and high-temperature performance. Iridium is valuable in industrial and scientific fields.

name: Platinum
definition: Platinum is a chemical element with symbol Pt and atomic number 78. It is a dense, malleable transition metal discovered by Antonio de Ulloa in 1748. Platinum occurs in platinum ores and alluvial deposits. Its isotopes include 194Pt and 195Pt. Platinum is used in jewelry, catalytic converters, and laboratory equipment. Platinum compounds are applied in catalysts, electronics, and medical devices. It has no biological role. Platinum is corrosion-resistant and stable. It enhances industrial, scientific, and technological applications. Platinum is highly valued for its durability and catalytic properties.

name: Gold
definition: Gold is a chemical element with symbol Au and atomic number 79. It is a dense, yellow transition metal known since ancient times. Gold occurs in alluvial deposits and ores. Its isotopes include 197Au. Gold is used in jewelry, electronics, and currency. Gold compounds are applied in dentistry, medicine, and chemical reactions. It has no biological role. Gold is malleable, ductile, and corrosion-resistant. It enhances financial, technological, and scientific applications. Gold is highly valued worldwide for its rarity and stability.

name: Mercury
definition: Mercury is a chemical element with symbol Hg and atomic number 80. It is a heavy, silvery liquid metal known since ancient times. Mercury occurs in cinnabar ore. Its isotopes include 202Hg. Mercury is used in thermometers, barometers, and fluorescent lamps. Mercury compounds are applied in industrial processes, dental amalgams, and chemical synthesis. It has no biological role but is toxic. Mercury is liquid at room temperature and conducts electricity. It enhances industrial, scientific, and technological applications. Mercury must be handled with care due to toxicity.

name: Thallium
definition: Thallium is a chemical element with symbol Tl and atomic number 81. It is a soft, gray post-transition metal discovered by Sir William Crookes in 1861. Thallium occurs in trace amounts in sulfide ores. Its isotopes include 203Tl and 205Tl. Thallium is used in electronics, optics, and historically in poisons. Thallium compounds are applied in glass, pharmaceuticals, and semiconductors. It has no biological role but is highly toxic. Thallium is reactive with air and moisture. It enhances specialized technological and industrial applications. Thallium must be handled carefully due to toxicity.

name: Lead
definition: Lead is a chemical element with symbol Pb and atomic number 82. It is a dense, malleable post-transition metal known since ancient times. Lead occurs in ores such as galena. Its isotopes include 204Pb, 206Pb, and 207Pb. Lead is used in batteries, radiation shielding, and alloys. Lead compounds are applied in paints, ceramics, and ammunition. It has no biological role but is toxic. Lead is corrosion-resistant and dense. It enhances industrial, technological, and scientific applications. Lead must be handled carefully due to toxicity.

name: Bismuth
definition: Bismuth is a brittle, silvery post-transition metal with symbol Bi and atomic number 83. It is primarily obtained from bismuthinite and as a byproduct of lead, copper, and tin refining. Bismuth is used in cosmetics, pharmaceuticals, and alloys. Bismuth compounds are applied in Pepto-Bismol, low-melting alloys, and fire detection devices. It has low toxicity compared to other heavy metals and no essential biological role. Bismuth is diamagnetic and has a low thermal conductivity. It is stable in air but reacts with strong acids. Bismuth enhances pharmaceutical, cosmetic, and metallurgical applications. It is valued in low-melting alloys and specialty materials.

name: Polonium
definition: Polonium is a highly radioactive metalloid with symbol Po and atomic number 84. Discovered by Marie and Pierre Curie in 1898, it occurs in uranium ores. Polonium isotopes are all radioactive, with 210Po being the most known. Polonium is used in research, nuclear batteries, and as a heat source in space applications. Its compounds are highly toxic and emit alpha particles. It has no biological role. Polonium is chemically reactive and must be handled with extreme caution. It enhances specialized nuclear and scientific applications. It is valuable only in scientific and industrial research due to radioactivity.

name: Astatine
definition: Astatine is a rare, radioactive halogen with symbol At and atomic number 85. It was first synthesized by Dale R. Corson, Kenneth Ross MacKenzie, and Emilio Segrè in 1940. Astatine occurs in trace amounts in uranium and thorium ores. Its isotopes are all radioactive, with 210At being common. Astatine has no commercial uses and is mainly studied for scientific research. Its compounds are highly unstable. It has no biological role. Astatine is chemically reactive and short-lived. It enhances knowledge in nuclear science and radiochemistry. It is valuable in research and theoretical studies.

name: Radon
definition: Radon is a colorless, radioactive noble gas with symbol Rn and atomic number 86. It is produced from the decay of radium in uranium ores. Radon isotopes include 222Rn, 220Rn, and 219Rn. Radon is used in research and medical applications, including cancer therapy. Its compounds are rare and radioactive. Radon has no biological role but is hazardous to health. It is chemically inert and accumulates in buildings. Radon enhances studies in nuclear physics, geology, and radiation. It is valuable in scientific research. Radon must be handled with strict safety precautions due to radioactivity.

name: Francium
definition: Francium is a highly radioactive alkali metal with symbol Fr and atomic number 87. It was discovered by Marguerite Perey in 1939. Francium occurs in trace amounts in uranium and thorium ores. Its isotopes are all radioactive, with 223Fr being the most stable. Francium has no commercial uses and is mainly studied for research. Francium is extremely reactive and decomposes rapidly. It has no biological role. Francium enhances nuclear research and studies of alkali metals. It is valuable only in scientific laboratories. Francium must be handled with extreme caution due to radioactivity.

name: Radium
definition: Radium is a radioactive alkaline earth metal with symbol Ra and atomic number 88. Discovered by Marie and Pierre Curie in 1898, it occurs in uranium ores. Its isotopes include 226Ra, 223Ra. Radium was historically used in luminous paints and medical therapies. Radium compounds are highly radioactive. It has no biological role. Radium is chemically reactive and unstable. Radium enhances nuclear research and medical studies. It is valuable in scientific research and specialized applications. Radium must be handled with extreme care due to radioactivity.

name: Actinium
definition: Actinium is a silvery radioactive metal with symbol Ac and atomic number 89. It was discovered by André-Louis Debierne in 1899. Actinium occurs in uranium and thorium ores. Its isotopes include 227Ac. Actinium is used in neutron sources, cancer therapy research, and scientific studies. Its compounds are radioactive. It has no biological role. Actinium is highly reactive and radioactive. It enhances nuclear science and research applications. It is valuable only in specialized laboratories. Actinium must be handled with extreme caution due to radioactivity.

name: Thorium
definition: Thorium is a radioactive metal with symbol Th and atomic number 90. It was discovered by Jöns Jacob Berzelius in 1828. Thorium occurs in monazite and thorite minerals. Its isotopes include 232Th. Thorium is used in nuclear fuel, ceramics, and research. Thorium compounds are radioactive. It has no biological role. Thorium is chemically reactive and moderately dense. It enhances nuclear research, energy, and industrial applications. Thorium must be handled with care due to radioactivity. Thorium is valuable in scientific, technological, and energy-related fields.

name: Protactinium
definition: Protactinium is a dense, radioactive metal with symbol Pa and atomic number 91. It was discovered by Kasimir Fajans and Oswald Göhring in 1913. Protactinium occurs in trace amounts in uranium ores. Its isotopes include 231Pa. Protactinium is mainly used for scientific research. Its compounds are highly radioactive and toxic. It has no biological role. Protactinium is chemically reactive and dense. It enhances studies in nuclear science, radiochemistry, and advanced materials. Protactinium must be handled under strict safety protocols due to radioactivity. It is valuable only in specialized research laboratories.

name: Uranium
definition: Uranium is a heavy, radioactive metal with symbol U and atomic number 92. It was discovered by Martin Heinrich Klaproth in 1789. Uranium occurs naturally in minerals such as uraninite. Its isotopes include 235U and 238U. Uranium is used as nuclear fuel, in weapons, and in research. Uranium compounds are applied in ceramics, pigments, and radiation shielding. It has no essential biological role. Uranium is dense, radioactive, and chemically reactive. It enhances nuclear energy, scientific research, and industrial applications. Uranium must be handled with extreme care due to radioactivity. It is valuable in energy and defense sectors.

name: Neptunium
definition: Neptunium is a radioactive metal with symbol Np and atomic number 93. It was discovered by Edwin McMillan and Philip H. Abelson in 1940. Neptunium is produced in uranium reactors and occurs in trace amounts naturally. Its isotopes include 237Np. Neptunium is used in nuclear research, reactors, and as a precursor for plutonium. Its compounds are highly radioactive. It has no biological role. Neptunium is chemically reactive and unstable. It enhances nuclear research, reactor design, and isotope production. Neptunium must be handled with extreme caution due to radioactivity. It is valuable in scientific laboratories.

name: Plutonium
definition: Plutonium is a radioactive metal with symbol Pu and atomic number 94. It was discovered by Glenn T. Seaborg, Edwin M. McMillan, Joseph W. Kennedy, and Arthur C. Wahl in 1940. Plutonium is produced in reactors from uranium-238. Its isotopes include 239Pu and 241Pu. Plutonium is used in nuclear weapons, reactors, and space power sources. Its compounds are highly radioactive and toxic. It has no biological role. Plutonium is chemically reactive and dense. It enhances nuclear energy, weapons research, and scientific applications. Plutonium must be handled under strict safety protocols due to radioactivity. It is valuable in specialized nuclear applications.

name: Americium
definition: Americium is a radioactive metal with symbol Am and atomic number 95. It was discovered by Glenn T. Seaborg, Ralph A. James, Leon O. Morgan, and Albert Ghiorso in 1944. Americium is produced in nuclear reactors from plutonium. Its isotopes include 241Am and 243Am. Americium is used in smoke detectors, industrial gauges, and research. Its compounds are radioactive. It has no biological role. Americium is chemically reactive and moderately dense. It enhances nuclear research, detection devices, and industrial applications. Americium must be handled with care due to radioactivity. It is valuable in scientific and industrial fields.

name: Curium
definition: Curium is a radioactive metal with symbol Cm and atomic number 96. It was discovered by Glenn T. Seaborg and Albert Ghiorso in 1944. Curium is produced in nuclear reactors from plutonium isotopes. Its isotopes include 242Cm and 244Cm. Curium is used in research, neutron sources, and space power applications. Its compounds are highly radioactive. It has no biological role. Curium is dense, radioactive, and chemically reactive. It enhances nuclear science, isotope studies, and space applications. Curium must be handled with extreme care due to radioactivity. It is valuable only in scientific research.

name: Berkelium
definition: Berkelium is a radioactive metal with symbol Bk and atomic number 97. It was discovered by Albert Ghiorso, Glenn T. Seaborg, and colleagues in 1949. Berkelium is produced in nuclear reactors from curium isotopes. Its isotopes include 247Bk. Berkelium is used in research and synthesis of heavier elements. Its compounds are radioactive. It has no biological role. Berkelium is chemically reactive and dense. It enhances nuclear research and studies of transuranic elements. Berkelium must be handled with strict safety measures due to radioactivity. It is valuable only in scientific laboratories.

name: Californium
definition: Californium is a radioactive metal with symbol Cf and atomic number 98. It was discovered by Albert Ghiorso, Stanley G. Thompson, and Glenn T. Seaborg in 1950. Californium is produced in nuclear reactors from curium. Its isotopes include 251Cf and 252Cf. Californium is used as a neutron source in reactors, medical applications, and research. Its compounds are radioactive. It has no biological role. Californium is dense, chemically reactive, and radioactive. It enhances nuclear research, isotope studies, and industrial applications. Californium must be handled with extreme care due to radioactivity. It is valuable in scientific research and technology.

name: Einsteinium
definition: Einsteinium is a synthetic, radioactive metal with symbol Es and atomic number 99. It was discovered in the debris of the first hydrogen bomb explosion in 1952. Einsteinium is produced in nuclear reactors from plutonium. Its isotopes include 252Es. Einsteinium is used only in scientific research. Its compounds are highly radioactive. It has no biological role. Einsteinium is chemically reactive and dense. It enhances studies in nuclear science, transuranic elements, and isotope research. Einsteinium must be handled with strict safety measures due to radioactivity. It is valuable only in research applications.

name: Fermium
definition: Fermium is a synthetic, highly radioactive metal with symbol Fm and atomic number 100. It was discovered in the debris of the first hydrogen bomb explosion in 1952. Fermium is produced in nuclear reactors or nuclear explosions. Its isotopes include 257Fm. Fermium has no commercial uses and is used only in scientific research. Its compounds are highly radioactive. It has no biological role. Fermium is chemically reactive and dense. It enhances nuclear research, isotope studies, and transuranic element research. Fermium must be handled with extreme care due to radioactivity. It is valuable only in scientific laboratories.

name: Mendelevium
definition: Mendelevium is a synthetic, radioactive metal with symbol Md and atomic number 101. It was discovered by Albert Ghiorso and Glenn T. Seaborg in 1955. Mendelevium is produced in particle accelerators. Its isotopes include 258Md. Mendelevium is used exclusively for research. Its compounds are radioactive. It has no biological role. Mendelevium is chemically reactive and dense. It enhances nuclear science, synthesis of transuranic elements, and isotope studies. Mendelevium must be handled with strict safety precautions due to radioactivity. It is valuable only in scientific research.

name: Nobelium
definition: Nobelium is a synthetic, radioactive metal with symbol No and atomic number 102. It was first reported by the Nobelium team in 1958 and later confirmed. Nobelium is produced in particle accelerators. Its isotopes include 259No. Nobelium has no commercial uses and is used only for research. Its compounds are radioactive. It has no biological role. Nobelium is chemically reactive and dense. It enhances nuclear research, transuranic element studies, and isotopic analysis. Nobelium must be handled with extreme care due to radioactivity. It is valuable only in scientific laboratories.
